content: I agree with the "medium" difficulty.  It definitely isn't "easy", in that the user has to solve 2 problems : converting the print page into unique characters and identifying substrings of minimal size containing those unique characters.  Because those 2 sub problems are not really co-mingled (in that you can solve 1 then the other) and easily identified as 2 different problems then it is definitely outside of "very hard".  There are some "hard" puzzles that are easier than this one, but by-and-large I think this puzzle is closest to the vast majority of "medium" puzzles and easier than the vast majority of "hard" puzzles.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle, a well-rounded challenge for a medium-level challenge,  because it effectively requires us to apply string manipulation and efficient algorithms.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle, quite easy to understand. Having a working program is easy but the lasts tests ask for some optimisation.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very approachable contribution yet tricky enough to deserve the medium label. The description is clear and the tests are plenty.

Small typo in the Input section: 

written in the syntax as described in the statement.
>> written in the syntax described in the statement.

Could you consider adding some more medium sized tests between Digits and Mixed?

I'm limit testing (read, writing very bad code) to see how far can I get away with a brute forcey approach but I seem to get timed out on the Mixed one.

Since Digits is ~200 x 10 and Mixed is ~6000 x 10, maybe a ~1000 x 10 at least?

Edit: Also maybe a constraint on w * h too? The possible maximum of 500 * 200 is far from being reached.

Goal
* Paragraph 2: Please change "alphabets" to "letters" (there are 26 letters in the English alphabet).

* Last paragraph:
(a) First sentence: Please change "element" to "elements".

(b) Next sentence: Please change "." to "," after "[2-5]".

(c) Next sentence: Please change to "Duplicates of characters are fine." ("character" to "characters", "is" to "are")

Input
* Next n lines:
(a) Suggest to change "a test case" to "an independent test case".

(b) Please change "a syntax" to "the syntax".

Cases
* Examples Validator is the only case which features partially overlapping ranges in wanted elements (a-g,e-n). Please include the same feature in 2 more tests and 1 more validator.

* Please feature fully overlapping ranges in wanted elements (e.g. e-z,e-z) in 2 tests and 2 validators.

* Please feature split continuous ranges in wanted elements (e.g. e-m,n-z) in 2 tests and 2 validators.

* Please feature all of the above but for digits in 2 tests and 2 validators (e.g. 2-5,3-9; 2-9,2-9; 2-4,5-9).

Thanks.

As promised previously, the source code is now embedded with plenty of format checking to ensure the input data conforms to specifications. Its purpose is to verify the correctness of the test cases more than to be used as a solution to submit.
Thanks your review. Done.

Sure, no problem. Could be ready in a few hours.

edit: 
w will be 500 as it is in use.
h could be limited to 20 or a bit more. The present cases are max at 19.
10k characters seems to be a limit of this site in each test case size.

I feel it needs the "as" in the sentence. Do you also mean that? I see it is already there, unsure it was put there myself or by others.

Thanks your comments and effort to try out the puzzle.
I believe both "as described" and "described" are correct.
I thought the 'as' was not needed, but @5DN1L is a native speaker and naturally a greater authority. If he claims that both are correct, then I apologize for the faulty correction.

I'm not a native speaker, so I can't claim I must be correct. But as far as I understand, "as described" is short for "as it is described", and "described" is short for "which is described", and both should be correct.

For your interest:
https://ell.stackexchange.com/questions/251270/as-past-participle

I see. I don't want to dig too deep into it, but when I first read it my impression was that "as described in the statement." refers to the previous part of the sentence as a whole, while just "described in the statement." unambiguously refers to the "syntax", which I claim was the original intent. Using "as" in that construction feels very odd to me.
No worries! @java_coffee_cup may consider deleting the word "as" to remove some confusion. "As" can be used in multiple ways, so it's understandable that it may create some confusion.

Great to learn an English lesson by reading both sides of arguments. By the simplicity principle that I believe - when a word adds no extra value to the sentence/passage, it can be and should be removed - I would go for removing it.
bro has a link for everything lol
In the last pair of cases, a comma seems to be missing in "m-z,k-n1,9"?
Sharp eyes! Fixed. Thanks.
